awd_titl_txt: CHS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Computer-Aided Design and Fabrication for General-Purpose Knit Manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
General-purpose fabrication of complex 3D shapes is possible today with industrial knitting machines, which provide a powerful alternative to conventional 3D printing, given their ability to use a wide range of feedstock to produce strong and durable artifacts that can withstand extreme deformations and stretch.  Machine knitting is already used in applications ranging from composite preforms for aircraft parts, soft robotics, and medicine to functional clothing like body-armor, cut-proof gloves, and everyday apparel.  However, controlling industrial knitting machines is a difficult task, as it involves determining an efficient sequence of low-level knitting machine instructions that produce a desired 3D form.  The goal of this project is to develop a complete framework, from computer-aided design to fabrication, for general-purpose knit manufacturing that will allow users to start with an arbitrary 3D shape, convert the shape to a virtual knit structure, customize the knit structure, and simulate the behavior of the result.   Project outcomes will enable widespread use of customized fabrication via machine knitting, with the potential to alter manufacturing practices and enable new products and applications in numerous industries, including robotics, furniture, automotive, space exploration, medicine, defense, and clothing.  A key contribution of this project will be simulating at the meso-scale, using a large database of common patterns to preview behavior at the many-stitch level. Additional broad impacts will derive from seeding interdisciplinary cross-department and cross-college collaborations in both institutions.

The key steps in the new CAD/CAM workflow, which involve converting arbitrary shapes to knit structures, will build on prior work by members of the team.  The project will involve: customization of the knit structure using both high- and low-level operations; live simulation of the knit structure by exploiting a novel data-driven patch-based approach that draws on calibration data captured from photographs; and low-level instruction generation and verification to include a hint-based scheduler that allows (optional) user control of the scheduling process.  Major contributions of this work will be the measurement-based simulation and the optimization steps of the pipeline, as well as the novel image-based yarn measurement technology to support them.  The integration of a hinting system, and the use of a topological verifier, are innovations that will impart to the work the flexibility and guarantee of correctness required to enable the proposed pipeline.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Knitting machines are a crucial part of how we make textiles. These industrial machines are used to produce approximately 30% of the clothing made in the world. Further, machine knitting use is growing in domains beyond clothing; including furniture, architecture, soft robotics, and composites. Machine knitting is useful in so many domains because knitting machines are programmable. They can make textiles with an extraordinarily wide range of textures, densities, thicknesses, and 3D shapes, all under programmatic control.

This award supported work that addressed the broad topic of improving the CAD (computer-aided design) process for knitting machines. Within this broad scope, we worked on developing the low-level algorithms and theory needed to develop and validate high-level systems; maintaining and documenting our low-level knitting language, "knitout"; and in prototyping novel knit artifacts to "stress-test" our knitting tools.

On the theoretical side, we first focused on the problem of "transfer planning" -- moving loops of yarn on a knitting machine's needle bed to where they need to be to continue knitting the pattern. Transfer planning is important because fast transfer plans are needed to make fully-automatic 3D-to-knitting CAD systems (of the sort we have developed previously) practical for manufacturing use.

We found that the results of transfer plans could be represented using the Artin Braid Group; and built on this insight to develop transfer plan equivalence checkers and optimal planners. Our optimal planner (though limited to relatively small problems) was able to demonstrate that existing state-of-the-art transfer approaches were -- as we suspected -- quadratically worse than optimal.

We continued our theoretical exploration by tackling the question of knitting program equivalence. We developed a new mathematical idea, the "fenced tangle", and used this idea to define, mathematically, what knitting programs "mean". This is an important step toward being able to optimize and translate knitting programs, because -- to be correct -- any optimizer or translator should not change the meaning of the program it is operating on. Before our fenced tangle definition, there was no mathematical way to demonstrate that any knitting program transformation was correct.

In addition to theoretical explorations of knitting correctness, we also exercised and improved our existing low-level knitting language "knitout" and the surrounding tools. We created knit.work (https://knit.work), a work-in-progress web page that explains machine knitting ideas with illustrations and sample programs. We maintained and updated the knitout live visualizer (https://textiles-lab.github.io/knitout-live-visualizer/), a two-view interface that visualizes knitting programs. We developed ports and updates for the knitout backend, including for the Kniterate prosumer knitting machine. And we developed and tested a method for estimating the amount of yarn that is used by a knitout program -- useful for planning yarn usage and, we hope, for future yarn simulation projects.

And, of course, we used knitout and related tools to develop knit patterns for other projects: an electrical-impedence-tomography-based sensing scarf that can detect its own position on the body as well as a range of gestures; a robot skin which can detect position and force of touches by using resistance measurements; and an open-source, complete-garment sweater pattern which can make a custom sweater from body measurements.

Overall, we did not completely solve the problem of computer-aided design for knitting machine programming; but we did build the mathematical theory that was previously missing, and improved our existing low-level software stack; leaving the world of knitting CAD on a better foundation than ever before. Further, we developed ways of illustrating, visualizing, and teaching about machine knitting that have brought this set of tools to many who would not have encountered it otherwise.
